timeline.subject: Jean Cachette

timeline.details: Rémy asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

prior_accusations.context: Wife executed for witchcraft, reportedly accused him during her trial of being witch for 3 years

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Cachette
notable_quotes.french: que quant on avoit des bestes malades qu'on disoit que ce faisoient Jenat et Jenaxe et que le plus souvent s'estoit faulte de les mal gouverner
notable_quotes.english: that when one had sick animals they said it was done by Jenat and Jenaxe and most often it was from poor management
notable_quotes.context: Response when accused of bewitching Demenge Didier Ydatte's cow

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Cachette
notable_quotes.french: une meschant femme et qu'il ne vouloit despendre sa vie a Flin
notable_quotes.english: a wicked woman and that he did not want to spend his life at Flin
notable_quotes.context: Referring to his wife after her accusation

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Cachette
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne savoit ce qu'il debvoit faire, priant dieu luy donner la grace dire la verité plustost que d'estre desrompu et tourmenté
notable_quotes.english: that he did not know what he should do, praying God to give him grace to tell the truth rather than be broken and tormented
notable_quotes.context: When threatened with torture on April 22

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Cachette
notable_quotes.french: que cela peult bien estre parce que ceste poudre noire est sy plaine de venin, qu'il en peult sortir des lazardes et aultres choses semblables
notable_quotes.english: that this could well be because this black powder is so full of venom that lizards and other similar things can come out of it
notable_quotes.context: Explaining how a 'lazarde' entered Anthoine Vannier's body

notable_quotes.speaker: daughter Fleurance
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle portoit ja avec elle Jehenne sa soeur
notable_quotes.english: that she was already bringing with her Jehenne her sister
notable_quotes.context: Grandmother's statement about taking granddaughter to sabbat

relationships.evidence_text: son of Gerardin Cachette of Flin

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over property, payment for masses attached to property, costs of soldiers, trial costs. Jean repeatedly claimed poverty. Father was leaving property to sister Claude instead of to Jean. Disputes over horse sales, grain loans, hay payment.

Jean Grand Jean forced to sell sick horse for this amount

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial with 33 witnesses. Jean Cachette confessed after threat of torture, then under actual torture. Initial confession was to 3.5 years of witchcraft, but under torture changed to 15 years. Many animal deaths (especially horses) and several human deaths attributed to him. Pattern of quarrels followed by harms. His wife had been executed for witchcraft shortly before. Economic stress evident (poverty, debts, property disputes, military costs). Sentenced to hot irons then burned alive. Notable that Jean blamed devil Persin for many harms and claimed to have been reluctant witch who was beaten for not doing more harm. Daughter Jehenne heavily implicated but not arrested in this trial.
